bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg discusses identification of the figures in Cornwell's painting for an upcoming "Hygeia" article that will feature a copy of the painting.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, August 22, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
August 22, 1941.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
First, I wish to thank you for the very kind letter
which you wrote to Dr. Fred Rankin. I will give Dr. Rankin two
days to think it over and then write him, sending you a carbon of
my letter.

With respect to the original letters of Dorothy Dix,
I certainly would like to have them but I would not wish to have
to spend much money for them.

As to the identification of the so-called anonymous
figure in the Yellow Fever painting, the one whom we wish to call
Jernigan at your suggestion, was really put there by Cornwell because
he wanted an interesting face with a mustache. It is actually the
face of one of the men photographed on the steps of the Officers'
Quarters whose name I do not recall. The resemblance is not too
striking but I do not think we will have any difficulty if we call
him Jernigan. Jernigan wore a mustache but, of course, I know
nothing about the color of his hair.

The seated figure on the porch might, from the stand-
point of historical justice, be Dr. Henry Carter or Roger Ames. I
do not have pictures of either of these two men.

At any rate, we will hold up our printing of the A.
M.A. inserts until we hear from you. It is possible for us to do
this as we are printing the insert for HYGEIA separately, for it
only carries the name of the painting and the artist. All other
material for HYGEIA which concerns the painting will be in the text.

I believe it might be well for you to write to Dr.
Fishbein direct and give him your suggestions (which he will turn
over to Miss Vernon) for the unnamed figures so that these may be
identified in any way you choose in the HYGEIA article. I do not
believe it is too late for them to make a correction even though
they were going to use the identifications made in the NEW YORK
SUNDAY MIRROR page.

Both Mr. Withington and I hope to attend the meet-
ing of the Wisconsin Medical Society at Madison September 10-12
but as is general with us it is difficult to know definitely more
than a day or two ahead.

I have no more of the colored proofs of the painting
as they have all been framed but I am enclosing two of the small
-2-
proofs such as will be used with the HYGEIA article.

Again I wish to thank you for the very kind letter
to Dr. Rankin.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
P.S. You would be amused at the trouble we are having with our
artist in getting the actual press printing job done. He is so
choosy about the coloring that he has our printer pretty well up
in the air. We are trying to follow his ideas as closely as poss-
ible but artists don't know much about printing and seem to expect
miracles.
G.A.K.
GAK:L
